1300 hours in and I'm still drawn back in every single day. Let me preface this by saying I have not touched the campaign, I am exclusively playing with sandbox and infinite money enabled. It's fun. If you have any interest in model railroads or transit design, this game is for you. It's a very vibey games at times, like the way I usually play is just having it on in the background while doing something else, and if I think of something I want to try I'll click on and try it out. It's incredibly good for getting my ideas for a model railroad or idealized transit system out "on paper" so to speak.

There are several (SEVERAL) things I would change about the game if I was designing it, but it's fairly simple to get around these problems with the incredibly simple mod loader. The mods have probably added like 1000 hours to this game for me. There are thousands to choose from, and some are pretty in depth and useful.

Excited for the third game, if you like trains this one is probably for you.

The first game I bought when I was a kiddo was Transport Tycoon Deluxe. And after some install problem, as I know crap all about games and operating systems, I played that game so incredibly much, and to this day I feel that allot of Transport Management games fall short of this gem.

But Transport Fever 2 is one of the best, and easily picks the number two spot. What I mostly played is teh campaign, as I am a sucker for stories and challenges in these types of games. And it had a really good approach! The route the game took was that of history, guiding you through significant and sometimes insignificant moments in history in which YOU have to manage the transportation of goods and people. I really got into it, and finished chapter one before I knew it.

See, the game divides itself into three "chapters"  and every chapter has about five to six mission, each in a different part of the world, but filtered by year.  A unique concept it is not, but it is fun and as a history idiot, I loved every second of this. The farthest I came was Chapter two, the mission in communist China. But, idiot that I am, I forgot to turn on Steam Cloud and now, after doing a fresh intall on my PC, I need to start back at the beginning, for the thrid time.

But dont get me wrong, I have absolutely no problem in doing that. Its a good game, and I find it relaxing to hover just above my train with the camera and just take it all in and enjoy the ride. Though it does take some time to get used to making lines that use more than 2 different transportation methods (first boat, then truck for example), I just cannot help but get that same feeling as I did when I was a kid and played Transport Tycoon Deluxe. Is it the same? No. But its damn good. So if ya love transport management games, grab this one, especially when its on discount. And remember, they developers are working on Transport Fever 3, and I cannot wait!
This game has been very fun. I am a large fan of locomotives, and this game has plenty of them.

Transport Fever 2 ‚Äì Steam Deck Gameplay ‚Äì 2025 Review

If you‚Äôve ever dreamed of running your own transport empire, building cities, and watching tiny digital people live their lives while you create a borderline tyrannical bus schedule, then Transport Fever 2 might be your next obsession.

But like any great journey, it has smooth tracks‚Ä¶ and some bumps that will make you mutter, ‚Äúwhy would you do this to me, game?‚Äù

üöÇ PROS
üé® Stunning Graphics

Transport Fever 2 is so pretty you might forget you're playing a logistics game and not browsing high-end travel brochures. Vehicles shine, landscapes pop, and the Steam Deck screen handles it all gracefully.

üèôÔ∏è Realistic, Detailed Design

Buildings, vehicles, and environments look like miniature handcrafted models placed inside a living museum.
Zooming in feels like inspecting a high-end diorama.

üöõ Excellent Transport Models

Trains? Gorgeous.
Planes? Gorgeous.
Ships? Gorgeous.
Even the trucks look like they were lovingly designed by someone who secretly wanted to work at a luxury car studio.

üåÜ Lively, Growing Cities

Your cities evolve realistically‚Äîpopulation growth, density, industry shifts. It‚Äôs satisfying watching your infrastructure fuel their development.

üéÆ Engaging Campaign Mode

Fun, humorous, and surprisingly gripping.
You start ‚Äújust one scenario,‚Äù then suddenly your coffee is cold and it‚Äôs three hours later.

üëÅÔ∏è Fantastic View Modes (Ride-Along & Follow Cameras)

One of the best parts of the game:
Ride a train across the entire map
Follow a bus through dense traffic
Trail a random citizen as they commute

These cinematic, travel-documentary-style views make the world feel alive and are weirdly relaxing.
It‚Äôs easy to lose time just‚Ä¶ sightseeing.
In a transport simulator.
And it‚Äôs glorious.

üß∞ CONS

üçº Tutorial Ends Too Early
Great start, then suddenly it‚Äôs like the tutorial says,
‚ÄúOkay, you‚Äôre a transport magnate now. Bye!‚Äù
You‚Äôre left holding 28 unprofitable routes and a dream.

üìò Steep Learning Curve for New Players
Once the tutorial leaves you on your own, the game unloads industry chains, maintenance needs, line balancing, and financial management all at once.
It‚Äôs like being handed the keys to a Boeing 747 because you once rode a bicycle.

üéØ FINAL VERDICT

Highly Recommended ‚Äî especially on Steam Deck.
Transport Fever 2 delivers impressive performance, beautiful visuals, deep gameplay, and endless replayability. Whether you're a veteran tycoon or willing to learn through a few early bankruptcies, this is a rewarding simulation experience.

And with Transport Fever 3 arriving in 2026, the hype is absolutely real.
If TF2 is the foundation, TF3 is shaping up to be something truly special.

Until then, TF2 is absolutely worth your time.

The visuals are decent, with detailed environments and vehicle models. However, they may not stand out compared to other modern simulation games, and some players might find the graphics somewhat dated.

The game play involves designing transportation routes, managing logistics, and balancing the economy. It provides a fair amount of depth, but the interface can be complex and sometimes unintuitive, especially for new players. The game offers both campaign and sandbox modes, but the learning curve can be steep.

Performance is generally stable, though large networks can cause lag on less powerful PCs. The user interface is functional but can feel cluttered, requiring some time to get used to.

Sound design is typical for the genre, with engine noises and ambient sounds, but it doesn't particularly stand out. The music is unobtrusive but may become repetitive.
end its lifespan and add variety, but official content updates have been somewhat limited.

Transport Fever 2 offers a solid transportation management experience, but it may not appeal to everyone. Its complexity can be off-putting for casual players, and the visuals, while serviceable, aren‚Äôt groundbreaking. It‚Äôs worth considering if you enjoy detailed logistics games and are willing to invest time into learning its systems.

A fairly straightforward yet attractive logistics game, where you carry freight and/or people to intended destinations using different modes of transportation in order to grow cities and generate profit. It is most compelling when trying to create the most efficient transportation lines and hubs when factoring in industry chains, city needs, and geography. Once you start generating large profits, it is not hard to 'beat' any map by linking all cities and industries, but fortunately replayability is good with different biomes and a random map generator. The graphics and soundtrack/sound effects are good.

negative.review:
It is with heavy hand that I decided to choose not recommend. I actually really enjoy the game, however, the couple of things that do not work, simply surpass any joy I had.

The good:
The tasks and scenarios are very well thought out (loved tongue-in-cheek German-speaking tourist tasks in Mallorca, H. Hughes and the movie of Genghis Khan and radioactive sand etc...). 

The bitter:
However, so many things you are just supposed to guess. The game explains only absolute basics in very beginning, which for most part, it is sufficient. But then the routes do not function or there is goal to reach in campaign and there is 9 times out of 10 simply no hint/warning/information why and how. Except when there is obvious issues like 2 trains on same tracks. 
I have once again gotten stuck, and this time I think I will just not return.
Hard and unforgiving to learn. I have no idea what I'm doing wrong most of the time and constantly have to google things or ask for help online.

Fairly polished and good-looking game, but unfortunately the economy model is so simple you can just exploit it by setting up fake demand for two goods, then arbitrarily shipping infinite amounts back and forth between two distant spots.

Game is probably good if you're looking to just sandbox build a bunch of complicated cargo hubs and watch it go, but if you're looking for an actual economic challenge, I can't recommend it.

Rail laying is extremely finicky. Crisscrossing rails doesn't work properly. The game doesn't select the best terrain modifications when laying rail or roads. Routes that should work don't but you can fix it by demolishing and rebuilding exactly as you had it which wastes time and resources. Production and delivery doesn't work in the way you expect or even like other transportation games. Diagnostic tools to figure out routing problems barely exist and often give an incorrect answer. Neither free play nor the campaign offer a tutorial.

Basically unplayable. The tutorial tells you to do things but not how. You will get stuck not able to deliver things because you have something in the wrong place but there is not possible way to know how to do it. The UI is overly complex also. I've never seen a building game with such a massive learning curve.

While game itself is a nice clone of old good Transport Tycoon with some improvements (mostly graphic), it has a serious drawback - campaign. Missions in campaign often has very vague description, barely indicating what players should do in what way. During Siberian mission only I've encoutered problem with mission with advertisement (there was no clue that it should be done in specific way) and with conspiracy mission (as nowhere was indicate how to recognise houses in question). And this fact, that many times during campaign player has to look through help and walkthroughs to simply find a solution (often far from any logic) is a bit annoying. Otherwise game is not that bad.

However, so many things you are just supposed to guess. The game explains only absolute basics in very beginning, which for most part, it is sufficient. But then the routes do not function or there is goal to reach in campaign and there is 9 times out of 10 simply no hint/warning/information why and how. Except when there is obvious issues like 2 trains on same tracks. 
I have once again gotten stuck, and this time I think I will just not return.
Hard and unforgiving to learn. I have no idea what I'm doing wrong most of the time and constantly have to google things or ask for help online.

Not recommended, great concept ruined by bugs

I really wanted to like Transport Fever 2. The idea is right up my alley, build networks, optimise logistics, watch cities grow, and on the surface it looks great. But the amount of bugs and confusion in the campaign has completely killed it for me.

Playing through the campaign, the missions are often convoluted and very unclear. Objectives are worded in a way where you‚Äôre never quite sure what exactly the game wants you to do or how it expects you to do it. I spent more time fighting the UI and trying to guess the logic behind the tasks than actually enjoying the transport building.

The worst part is the resource system. A lot of the resource gathering and allocation seems automated, but it regularly assigns lines to resources that simply aren‚Äôt available. When I tried to fix it by setting the platforms/terminals manually, it still didn‚Äôt work properly, trucks would happily drive back and forth with empty loads even though there were goods waiting, or they‚Äôd ignore the platform assignment and behave as if nothing had changed.

After enough missions like this, it stopped being fun and just became frustrating. When the core loop is ‚Äúdebug the game‚Äù instead of ‚Äúbuild a transport empire,‚Äù it‚Äôs time to put it down. Until the campaign logic and resource handling are cleaned up, I can‚Äôt recommend this.

Fairly polished and good-looking game, but unfortunately the economy model is so simple you can just exploit it by setting up fake demand for two goods, then arbitrarily shipping infinite amounts back and forth between two distant spots.

Game is probably good if you're looking to just sandbox build a bunch of complicated cargo hubs and watch it go, but if you're looking for an actual economic challenge, I can't recommend it.

Rail laying is extremely finicky. Crisscrossing rails doesn't work properly. The game doesn't select the best terrain modifications when laying rail or roads. Routes that should work don't but you can fix it by demolishing and rebuilding exactly as you had it which wastes time and resources. Production and delivery doesn't work in the way you expect or even like other transportation games. Diagnostic tools to figure out routing problems barely exist and often give an incorrect answer. Neither free play nor the campaign offer a tutorial.

While game itself is a nice clone of old good Transport Tycoon with some improvements (mostly graphic), it has a serious drawback - campaign. Missions in campaign often has very vague description, barely indicating what players should do in what way. During Siberian mission only I've encoutered problem with mission with advertisement (there was no clue that it should be done in specific way) and with conspiracy mission (as nowhere was indicate how to recognise houses in question). And this fact, that many times during campaign player has to look through help and walkthroughs to simply find a solution (often far from any logic) is a bit annoying. Otherwise game is not that bad.
Trains are stupid, stops only at platforms where is cargo. No idea how signals works, After experience with TT/D and Mashinky, this looks like disaster :-(

Guess what I downloaded? A puzzle game!
Spent my 4 Hours in game trying to figure out why supply of whiskey isn't reaching the pub.
Spoiler: Never figured it out.

Basically unplayable. The tutorial tells you to do things but not how. You will get stuck not able to deliver things because you have something in the wrong place but there is not possible way to know how to do it. The UI is overly complex also. I've never seen a building game with such a massive learning curve.

Many different tries to make this work.  So I earned enough money to build a complete line.   Crude to refine.  Refine to fuel.  Fuel to town.  All at the same time so the load manager would not freak out.   The load manager freaked out anyway.  Will post a screenshot.  At first it gave me the refined.  Then my trucks started backing up.   AGAIN.  Trains / trucks - it make no difference.   A game that decides on its own  NO - is a NO BUY review.
Wow. 5 minutes was all i could take. Literally no instructions. Rotate the Depot....great how TF do I rotate things exactly?? Screw this.
Confusing UI, bad tutorial. Dissapointed.
I hate this game

The in-game tutorial in the campaigns is appalling bad.  I don't know who is responsible for this, but it's like the creator built it with all the in-house knowledge, but didn't look at it from the beginner's perspective at all. Terrible in that there's instructions, but not how to execute the instructions.  Suggested buildings are not in the menu of choices named the same.  When you get stuck there's no suggestions or demonstrations.  I've spend good money on this game but can't seem to get ahead.  When I look at Youtube videos for help, they seem similarly perplexed.  Why is this so poorly supported from a training view.

The missions are fine but I want to play more sandbox mode. The game is just a clicker, it's so easy to earn money. There is no challenge. In sandbox there are industries everywhere, even if you select as few as possible. There is no logic in how they are placed. They are just spread all over the map. 

You earn so much money. It‚Äôs a great idea to start with a loan, but after you build one train line (even on hard difficulty) you can quickly pay it off. There is no challenge at all. I started with everything set to as difficult as possible. This is a bit sad since it could be a really nice game. 

Quite hard to get an overview of what each line earns. I think it‚Äôs per year, but a train can take over a year (!) to travel, so what‚Äôs shown can vary a lot.
Tutorial has a lot of bugs and badly explained objectives.
It is so painfull to play this game. I don't know if i am just unlucky but it has been a bug fest so far.
This game is fun but only buy it if it is under $5. It has a LOT of rough edges that will likely never be fixed.
I'm not sure, I like the graphics and gameplay. What annoys me is the trains can't automatically find paths like in OpenTTD, That should be changed for the third one. Other than that I don't mind it.

Tortuous and patronising campaign - I gave up doing the cheesy extra missions in chapter 1 and have stopped altogether after the first main mission of chapter 2. Buy an aeroplane, sell an aeroplane, buy an aeroplane, sell an aeroplane, buy an aeroplane, sell an aeroplane, buy an aeroplane, sell an aeroplane, buy an aeroplane, sell an aeroplane... what, why? And then there's the core of the game - routing of goods - which is frustrating to set up and easy to break, the lack of any competition given what you're doing, the music - which thankfully you can switch off - and because I've been sitting around waiting, the jarring, immersion breaking things. English street names and announcements across the planet. Announcements for passengers to Birmingham or Canada being made at airports when you've literally just started to build the first plane in existence for travel. One or two of these would be tolerable, but put together they're painful. The third instalment looks pretty, but unless the mechanics change, it won't be on my list.
This is possibly a great game but I wasn't able to pass the horrendous tutorial.

Campaign is an important aspect of a game. Well, this game's campaign was clearly designed by a sadistic noob who's only goal was to inflict as much pain as possible on all the idiots buying this product based on the very positive reviews thinking they might find an inch of enjoyment in completing the campaign. But no, there is no enjoyment. There is no challenge, there is only pain. Stupid, silly missions, no teaching on the complex dynamics of the game, just idiotic tasks that require you to destroy all you've done over and over again and to wait unnecessarily long time to complete painstakingly idiotic tasks that go against any logic. I don't care, at this point, how good the free play is, because after spending 80 hours completing the campaign I'm literally exhausted. And I completed it because I kept hoping that it would get better. But no, it doesn't. The last mission (Shanghai) was the apex of idiocy and whoever designed it should be banned from ever working in the gaming industry for 10 generations.

Has one of the most unintuitive train line networking system to ever exist. It will make you scratch your head, and it will make you ask even god himself what and why does it not or do work (He does not even dare answer for not even he knows). 

This must be how it feels to be a programmer.

I kept on playing the game expecting it to get harder or complicated. Unfortunately the game lack depth. Even though you are granted with some options it still fails to feel nuanced.
For some reason I find it very difficult to play buildings in the tutorial, not recommended.
